title: Trump Administration Expedites Challenge to California on Auto-Emission Rules
text:
The Trump administration is pressing regulators to accelerate the rollout of new tailpipe-emission rules, an attempt to strike back at California for cutting a side deal with several auto makers to set standards that are tougher than those proposed by the administration, according to people familiar with the White House’s plans.

As part of that effort, officials could move within the next few days to curb California’s influence on the car industry, say these people and others familiar with the administration’s thinking. That could be a more aggressive attempt to end its longstanding authority to set its own emissions rules or threats to dissuade auto makers from collaborating further with the state, these people say.

The White House has been proposing to ease requirements originally set under the Obama administration. The Environmental Protection Agency and the U.S. Department of Transportation are overseeing the rule-making process.

Auto makers are worried the administration’s efforts are too confrontational with California and will result in a protracted legal battle between the federal government and the nation’s most populous state. That could force manufacturers to meet two sets of tailpipe-emissions standards for selling cars and trucks in the U.S., a scenario industry executives say will compromise future vehicle planning.

To ensure some certainty in future years, Ford Motor Co. , Honda Motor Co., BMW AG and Volkswagen AG struck an agreement this summer with California to voluntarily meet a new set of standards that are tougher than the White House’s proposal—but tamer than the Obama era ones.

The companies have said the pact was intended to show support for a single, nationwide vehicle-emissions standard, rather than a patchwork of state-by-state rules. But the move by California frustrated some administration officials who viewed it as a disruptive power play, said one senior official and others briefed on the White House’s reaction.

“Quite frankly our rule is realistic, it’s a realistic and transparent fuel-economy standard that will reduce auto pollution—unlike what California is doing,” White House spokesman Judd Deere said. “Our focus is finalizing the rule.”

Spokespeople for the California governors’ office and the California Air Resources Board didn’t return a request to comment.

California has a federal waiver to set its own emissions rules, which the Trump administration wants to revoke to limit the state’s influence over the auto industry. California sets its own greenhouse gas emissions under a waiver first granted by the EPA in 2009 and again in 2013.

Thirteen other states follow California’s rules—representing roughly one-third of overall U.S. auto sales last year—giving California’s air regulators wide power over national standards.

Other auto makers, such as Toyota Motor Corp. and General Motors Co. so far have been reluctant to join the California agreement, but their executives are also concerned about the uncertainty of a legal fight.

On Thursday, GM Chief Executive Mary Barra met with President Trump at the White House for a scheduled meeting to discuss jobs and trade issues, including China, as well as the administration’s efforts to reshape the fuel-economy requirements.

In completing the new rules, administration officials have also taken steps to enhance their chances of ending California’s waiver by separating the effort from the broader emissions rule-making process, say people familiar with the strategy.

The White House’s efforts to expedite the final rule-making process still faces high legal hurdles, and its resources are stretched by other deregulatory efforts—and now a major hurricane. It is already months behind schedule in relaxing the current requirements, a priority for the White House since the start of Mr. Trump’s presidency.

Within days of his taking office, car companies began lobbying Mr. Trump for relief on the Obama era standards, arguing they were too strict and didn’t take into account the shift in consumer preference for trucks and SUVs that burn more fuel.

Executives, however, didn’t expect such a drastic rollback by the administration, which wants to freeze the Obama era fuel economy standards at 2020 levels, or roughly 37 miles a gallon. The Obama-era rules call for annual increases in fuel economy to an average of roughly 50 miles a gallon by mid-decade.

Separating the effort to strip California of its waiver from the rest of the emissions rule-making process would be a new, more aggressive step. It could insulate the challenge from being overturned if the administration loses a court battle on the merits or rationale of its proposed changes to the fuel-economy mandates, according to legal experts.

“Trump, as a politician, is concerned about the visuals, the theatrics of it, how it plays with the public,” said Myron Ebell, a former member of Mr. Trump’s transition team and the director of the Center for Energy and Environment at the Competitive Enterprise Institute, a conservative think tank. “He wants to put California in a box.”

Car makers, California and Trump administration officials have said from the presidency’s earliest days they wanted to preserve one national fuel-economy standard for all 50 states. But negotiations with California to align their rules have been fraught, and the Trump administration said earlier this year it would no longer work with state officials to reshape the rules, breaking off talks.

California has responded with lawsuits and promises of more legal action. State officials first sued the EPA last year over its move to reconsider the Obama-era targets and have indicated they would challenge any threat to its emissions waiver in court.

—Mike Colias contributed to this article.

Write to Timothy Puko at tim.puko@wsj.com and Ben Foldy at Ben.Foldy@wsj.com
description: The Trump administration is pressing regulators to speed up the rollout of new tailpipe-emission rules, an attempt to strike back at California for making a side deal with several auto makers.
